threats.title: Phishing
threats.description: The attempt to obtain sensitive information or data, such as usernames, passwords and credit card details, by disguising oneself as a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication.
threats.mitigation:
Protect computer by using security software, set the software to update automatically so it can deal with any new security threats.
Protect mobile phone by setting software to update automatically, these updates could give critical protection against security threats.
Multi-factor authentication makes it harder for scammers to log in to your accounts if they do get your username and password.
If you get a phishing email or text message, report it, the information given can help fight the scammers.
Computer training should include modules that teach users to recognize security threats, potentially dangerous websites, phishing attempts, and another social engineering that they may encounter.

threats.title: Weak Antivirus Software
threats.description: Weak antivirus software can lead to hackers improving their methods and find ways to to work around this weak software. As a result, these attacks can be difficult to detect and can do a lot of damage before any action can be taken.
threats.mitigation: Organizations should take a multi-pronged approach. This includes using multiple products that specialize in email scanning, proxy filtering, and detection of malware. It’s also imperative that security products are kept updated.

threats.title: Repudiation attack
threats.description: A repudiation attack happens when an application or system does not adopt controls to properly track and log users’ actions, thus permitting malicious manipulation or forging the identification of new actions.
threats.mitigation: Implement auditing to catch and trace these activities.

threats.title: Browser Extenstions and Plugins
threats.description: Extensions and plugins can be used to offer improved experiences online, and to add helpful functionality to websites. However some are created with malicious intent and others are simply poorly made, creating vulnerabilities in the browsers in which they are installed. These can provide a pathway for hackers to steal data or install ransomware.
threats.mitigation: Organisations can take action by creating a policy that forbids users from installing extensions and plugins that don’t have a business purpose. They can even create a list of allowed extensions and plugins and take action to block those that are not on the approved list.

threats.title: Botnet Malware
threats.description: A botnet’s strategy essentially determines its development, laying the foundation of bots for further exploitation. Once an attacker has compromised a machine on a network, there is a possibility that all vulnerable computers on that network become infected.
threats.mitigation:
Use a firewall
Upadate your software and systems to the lastest version
Get protection that works at DNS-level
Manage admin rights in the organisation

threats.title: Cryptojacking
threats.description: Cryptojacking is the unauthorized use of someone else’s computer to mine cryptocurrency. Hackers do this by infecting a website or online ad with JavaScript code that auto-executes once loaded in the victim’s browser.
threats.mitigation:
Incorporate the cryptojacking threat into your security awareness training, focusing on phishing-type attempts to load scripts onto users’ computers. 
Install an ad-blocking or anti-cryptomining extension on web browsers.

cells.description: a computer program with a graphical user interface for displaying and navigating between web pages.

threats.title: DDoS Attack
threats.description: A malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server, service or network by overwhelming the target or its surrounding infrastructure with a flood of Internet traffic.
threats.mitigation:
Create a blackhole route and funnel traffic into that route. When blackhole filtering is implemented without specific restriction criteria, both legitimate and malicious network traffic is routed to a null route, or blackhole, and dropped from the network.
A Web Application Firewall (WAF) is a tool that can assist in mitigating a layer 7 DDoS attack.

threats.description: Failing to implement all the security controls for a server or web application, or implementing the security controls, but doing so with errors.
threats.title: Security Misconfiguration
threats.mitigation:
Configure server to prevent unauthorized access, directory listing, etc.
Consider running scans and doing audits periodically to help detect future misconfigurations or missing patches.

threats.description: Access control enforces policy such that users cannot act outside of their intended permissions. Failures typically lead to unauthorized information disclosure, modification or destruction of all data, or performing a business function outside of the limits of the user.
threats.title: Broken Access Control
threats.mitigation:
Deny access to functionality by default.
Use Access control lists and role-based authentication mechanisms.

threats.title: Sensitive Data Exposure
threats.description: Data exposure is when data is left exposed in a database or server for anyone to see. Sensitive data can be exposed when configuration details for systems and applications are left unsecured online.
threats.mitigation: Implement high-quality security software. Install and use a software suite that includes malware and virus protection and always keep it updated

threats.title: Broken Authentication
threats.description: Application functions related to authentication and session management are often implemented incorrectly, allowing attackers to compromise passwords, keys, or session tokens, or to exploit other implementation flaws to assume other users’ identities temporarily or permanently.
threats.mitigation:
Implement multi-factor authentication
Control Session Length. Every web application automatically ends sessions at some point, either after logout, a period of no activity, or a certain length of time.

threats.title: SQL Injection
threats.description: SQL injection is a code injection technique, used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field for execution.
threats.mitigation:
Web application firewall (WAF) – either software or appliance-based – to help filter out malicious data.
Continuously monitor SQL statements from database-connected applications. This will help identify rogue SQL statements and vulnerabilities. Monitoring tools that utilize machine learning and/or behavioral analysis can be especially useful.

threats.description: The attempt to obtain sensitive information or data, such as usernames, passwords and credit card details, by disguising oneself as a trustworthy entity in an electronic communication.
threats.title: Phising
threats.mitigation:
Protect computer by using security software, set the software to update automatically so it can deal with any new security threats.
Protect mobile phone by setting software to update automatically, these updates could give critical protection against security threats.
Multi-factor authentication makes it harder for scammers to log in to your accounts if they do get your username and password.
If you get a phishing email or text message, report it, the information given can help fight the scammers.
Computer training should include modules that teach users to recognize security threats, potentially dangerous websites, phishing attempts, and another social engineering that they may encounter.

threats.title: Improper file and directory permissions
threats.description: Improper permissions allow the attacker to access restricted files or directories and modify or delete their contents.
threats.mitigation: Perform regular security protocol assessments

threats.title: Unpatched Security Flaws
threats.description: Unpatched vulnerabilities allow attackers to run a malicious code by leveraging a known security bug that has not been patched.
threats.mitigation: Run security checks on third-party platforms and make sure that any security weaknesses are resolved.

threats.title: Administrative accounts with default passwords
threats.mitigation: Update passwords regularly and use multi-factor authentication
threats.description: A default password is a standard pre-configured password for a device. Such passwords are the default configuration for many devices and lead to serious secuirty risks

threats.title: SSL certificates and encryption settings not properly configured
threats.mitigation:
Perform regular security protocol assessments.
opt for cybersecurity automation through a data protection platform.
threats.description: The most common cause of a "certificate not trusted" error is that the certificate installation was not properly completed on the server (or servers) hosting the site.

threats.title: Tampering Based Attacks
threats.description: Attackers insert malicious files that change the configuration of a network or system, modify user credentials to gain access to sensitive data, or tamper with log files.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce Encryption for Data-at-Rest and Data-in-Transit.
Copy-on-Write File Systems.

threats.title: Improper File and Directory Permissions
threats.description: Improper permissions allow the attacker to access restricted files or directories and modify or delete their contents.
threats.mitigation: Perform regular security protocol assessments

threats.title: Administrative accounts with default passwords
threats.description: A default password is a standard pre-configured password for a device. Such passwords are the default configuration for many devices and lead to serious secuirty risks
threats.mitigation: Update passwords regularly and use multi-factor authentication

threats.title: NoSQL Attack
threats.description: NoSQL injection vulnerabilities allow attackers to inject code into commands for databases that don’t use SQL queries. Code is injected and executed on the server in the language of the web application, potentially allowing arbitrary code execution.
threats.mitigation: Avoid using unsanitized user inputs in application code, especially when building database queries.

threats.title: Ransomeware Attack
threats.description: Ransomware is malicious software that infects your computer and displays messages demanding a fee to be paid in order for your system to work again.
threats.mitigation:
Install security updates as soon as they become available in order to fix exploitable bugs in your products.
Use the latest versions of OSs and applications to take advantage of the latest security features.
Disable or constrain scripting environments and macros.

threats.title: Excessive Database Privileges
threats.description: Database users may have different privileges and users may abuse them. Types include excessive privilege abuse, legitimate privileges abuse and unused privilege abuse.
threats.mitigation:
Deploy and uphold a strict access and privileges control policy.
Don’t grant excessive privileges to company employees and revoke outdated privileges in time.

threats.title: Weak Audit Trail
threats.description: If a database is not audited it represents risks of noncompliance with national and international sensitive data protection regulations. All database events shall be recorded and registered automatically and it’s obligatory to use automatic auditing solutions.
threats.mitigation: Use automatic auditing solutions that impose no additional load on database performance.

threats.title: Database Backups Exposure
threats.description: Database back-up files left completely unprotected from attack. As a result, there will be security breaches happening through database backup leaks.
threats.mitigation:
Encrypt both databases and backups, storing data in encrypted form allows secure both production and back-up copies of databases.
Audit both the database and backups, doing this helps to see who has been trying to get access to sensitive data.

threats.title: DDoS Attack
threats.description: This type of attacks slows down a database server and can even make it unavailable to all users.
threats.mitigation:
Harden the TCP/IP stack by applying the appropriate registry settings to increase the size of the TCP connection queue.
Decrease the connection establishment period.
Employ dynamic backlog mechanisms to ensure that the connection queue is never exhausted.
Use a network Intrusion Detection System (IDS).

threats.title: Tampering threat
threats.description: Attackers insert malicious files that change the configuration of a network or system, modify user credentials to gain access to sensitive data, or tamper with log files.
threats.mitigation:
Enforce Encryption for Data-at-Rest and Data-in-Transit.
Copy-on-Write File Systems.

threats.title: Repudiation threat
threats.description: A repudiation attack happens when an application or system does not adopt controls to properly track and log users’ actions, thus permitting malicious manipulation or forging the identification of new actions.
threats.mitigation: Implement auditing to catch and trace these activities.

threats.title: DDoS threat
threats.description: A malicious attempt to disrupt the normal traffic of a targeted server, service or network by overwhelming the target or its surrounding infrastructure with a flood of Internet traffic.
threats.mitigation:
Create a blackhole route and funnel traffic into that route. When blackhole filtering is implemented without specific restriction criteria, both legitimate and malicious network traffic is routed to a null route, or blackhole, and dropped from the network.
A Web Application Firewall (WAF) is a tool that can assist in mitigating a layer 7 DDoS attack.

threats.title: Unrestricted access to data
threats.mitigation: Only carefully audited modules should be permitted to run background worker processes.
threats.description: Allows you to limit background data used by apps, but whitelist anything that want to have unrestricted access. This means background data is disabled for every app by default, then you can pick and choose where to grant unlimited access.

threats.mitigation:
